Award.AwardTitle: HSI Conference: Catalyzing Progress in Undergraduate STEM Education with Insights from Midwestern HSIs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
A conference on enhancing undergraduate STEM education at Hispanic-Serving Institutions will be organized and hosted at Northeastern Illinois University (NEIU) in Chicago, Illinois. The conference will attract participants from regional public two-year and four-year public and private Hispanic-Serving Institutions (HSIs) in the Midwest. The conference will weave together two intersecting threads: 1) Best practices in STEM pedagogy, and 2) HSI identity. A particular focus will be students' transition points and momentum points (academic achievements that tend to propel a student forward). These transition points include K-12 to college, two-year to four-year, four-year to graduate school, and military service to college. The conference was proposed in response to a Dear Colleague Letter (17-092 - Improving Undergraduate STEM Education in Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs)) issued by the National Science Foundation (NSF) calling for submission of conference proposals to inform the design of NSF's new Hispanic-Serving Institution program, to be established in fiscal year 2018.

Through keynote speakers, panels, workshops, lectures, and breakout sessions, the conference will integrate the two threads by exploring tested practices in STEM education and pedagogy, and identifying issues related to HSI identity, including opportunities, needs, and challenges faced by these institutions. The overarching goal of the conference will be to explore potential actionable solutions to challenges and opportunities in undergraduate STEM education at HSIs. By identifying best practices, novel pedagogical approaches, and diverse institutional strategies, as well as providing a medium to catalyze networking and collaborative initiatives among regional HSIs, the proposed conference will contribute in important ways to the enhancement and improvement of STEM educational activities. POR.DRECONTENT:
A conference on “Catalyzing Progress in Undergraduate STEM Education with Insights from Midwestern HSIs” was held at Northeastern Illinois University El Centro campus May 3-4, 2018.

Intellectual Merit: The conference developed participants’ understanding of building capacity in undergraduate STEM education at Midwestern Hispanic-Serving Institutions. The opening keynote address highlighted institutional strategies for developing talent in STEM graduates. Other keynotes concentrated on supporting student success in STEM programs, facilitating student transition from college to the workforce, pedagogical methods for optimal STEM learning, including active learning, community building, peer-led team learning, the learning assistant model, and affinity research group strategies. Breakout sessions and roundtable discussions were dedicated to exploration of HSI identity, STEM discipline-based approaches, and a student panel. Participants left the conference with ideas on how to access culturally relevant curriculum materials, invest in faculty professional development, and promote interdisciplinary approaches and collaborations, which are a strength of HSIs and other MSIs.

Broader Impacts: All sessions supported participants’ understanding of how to help expand their institutions’ ability to produce students ready to join STEM careers or workforce. Based on attendee participation and feedback, results of the project showed that recruitment and retention in STEM courses and consequently in STEM majors was a primary concern for all institutions represented, particularly the HSIs. A lack of financial resources and infrastructure identified by conference participants was viewed as making STEM education at HSIs challenging. Poor academic preparedness of students also was seen as a significant issue. However, participants were optimistic about securing institutional and departmental buy-in for capacity-building and were excited to learn about the new HSI Program at NSF to be able to work around many of the issues identified at the conference. 

One hundred fifty-nine participants attended. Ninety-four percent of attendees were from Illinois. Faculty were 48% of attendees, administrators were 18%, and staff were 14%. A plurality of attendees (49%) were from four-year HSIs or MSIs, and 29% were from two-year institutions. The majority of attendees (63%) had never served as a PI or co-PI on an NSF grant.
